content: The "Landmine Elimination Act of 1997" is the short title of this Act. It includes findings related to landmines. Congress finds that on August 4, 1995, the Senate voted to impose a moratorium on US use of anti-personnel landmines starting in February 1999. Additionally, on April 3, 1996, senior retired US military officers urged the President to ban the production, stockpiling, sale, and use of these landmines, stating it would be humane and militarily responsible. The United States Armed Forces, NATO, Vietnam, and Desert Storm generals urged the President to ban anti-personnel landmines due to their impact on military personnel. In Vietnam, 7,318 US military personnel were killed and 56,783 injured by landmines. In Bosnia, at least 204 soldiers under UN command were injured and 20 killed by landmines. The United States is actively pursuing an international agreement to ban anti-personnel landmines. The Organization of American States and the Organization of African Unity have declared goals to establish landmine-free zones. Canada also announced negotiations for a treaty banning landmines to be completed in Ottawa in December 1997. The Organization of African Unity adopted the goal of establishing Africa as an anti-personnel landmine free zone. In December 1996, the United Nations General Assembly passed a resolution to pursue a treaty banning the use, stockpiling, production, and transfer of anti-personnel landmines. Formal negotiations on the Ottawa treaty are scheduled to begin in Oslo, Norway in September 1997. SEC. 3. RESTRICTION ON NEW DEPLOYMENTS OF ANTI-PERSONNEL LANDMINES. Beginning on January 1, 2000, no funds may be used for new deployments of anti-personnel landmines. The Secretary of Defense must submit a report to Congress within 180 days outlining alternative actions for landmines on the Korean Peninsula. Consultations with various experts are required for the report. The President has the authority to delay the restriction if needed. The President can delay the restriction on new deployments of anti-personnel landmines if necessary. The Secretary of Defense must submit a report to Congress certifying the necessity of new deployments of anti-personnel landmines on the Korean Peninsula for defense purposes. The report should also detail efforts to implement proposed alternatives and similar suggestions by military officials. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "anti-personnel landmine" refers to munitions designed to detonate by contact with a person, causing harm or death. "New deployments of anti-personnel landmines" are those placed after January 1, 2000. The term "anti-personnel landmine" refers to munitions designed to detonate upon contact with a person, causing harm or death. Exclusions include command-detonated Claymore munitions.
